required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Diagnoses Associated With Persistent Elevation of Creatine Kinase
clinical_study.official_title: Diagnoses Associated With Persistent Elevation of Creatine Kinase

brief_summary.textblock: Serum creatinine kinase (CK) level varies with age, gender, race and physical activity. For these reasons there is no normal serum CK level. Many pathological situations cause hyperCKemia, such as neuromuscular disorders (muscular dystrophy, inflammatory myositis, mitochondrial myopathy) and multiple systemic causes. The diagnostic approach to pauci or asymtomatic hyperCKemia can therefore be difficult and lead to multiple, and sometimes invasive tests, such as muscle biopsy. This study aims to describe the diagnoses associated with persistent elevation of serum creatine kinase and to precise the role of the muscule biopsy.

primary_outcome.time_frame: at the end of all investigations, an average of 12 months
primary_outcome.description: The final diagnosis, as written in the medical record at the end of the investigations in the ward of internal medicin, responsible for the elevation of creatine kinase between: inflammatory myositis, mitochondrial myopathy, muscular dystrophy, non neuromuscular pathology

secondary_outcome.time_frame: at the end of all investigations, an average of 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: Among the patients who underwent a muscle biopsy, number of anormal biopsies that contributed to make the final diagnosis responsible of the elevation of creatine kinase

secondary_outcome.time_frame: at the end of all investigations, an average of 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: association between the initial clinical presentation and the final diagnosis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: at the end of all investigations, an average of 12 months
secondary_outcome.description: association between the initial paraclinical presentation and the final diagnosis

study_pop.textblock: Patients hospitalised in the ward of internal medicin of Nancy University Hospital or UNEOS General Hospital of Metz between 2009 and 2018.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients hospitalised in a ward of internal medicin
- having a persistent elevation of serum creatine kinase >3 times the upper normal laboratory value, repeated for 2 times
Exclusion Criteria:
- known neuro-muscular disease causing elevation of creatine kinase
- evident post-traumatic cause responsible for the elevation of creatine kinase
- incomplete medical records
